member.name: T:QuickWPFMonthCalendar.My.MyWpfExtension
member.summary: Module used to define the properties that are available in the My Namespace for WPF

member.name: P:QuickWPFMonthCalendar.My.MyWpfExtension.Application
member.summary: Returns the application object for the running application

member.name: P:QuickWPFMonthCalendar.My.MyWpfExtension.Computer
member.summary: Returns information about the host computer.

member.name: P:QuickWPFMonthCalendar.My.MyWpfExtension.User
member.summary: Returns information for the current user. If you wish to run the application with the current Windows user credentials, call My.User.InitializeWithWindowsUser().

member.name: P:QuickWPFMonthCalendar.My.MyWpfExtension.Log
member.summary: Returns the application log. The listeners can be configured by the application's configuration file.

member.name: P:QuickWPFMonthCalendar.My.MyWpfExtension.Windows
member.summary: Returns the collection of Windows defined in the project.

member.name: T:QuickWPFMonthCalendar.My.Resources.Resources
member.summary: A strongly-typed resource class, for looking up localized strings, etc.

member.name: P:QuickWPFMonthCalendar.My.Resources.Resources.ResourceManager
member.summary: Returns the cached ResourceManager instance used by this class.

member.name: P:QuickWPFMonthCalendar.My.Resources.Resources.Culture
member.summary: Overrides the current thread's CurrentUICulture property for all resource lookups using this strongly typed resource class.

member.name: T:QuickWPFMonthCalendar.Appointment
member.summary: This class is actually a stripped-down version of the actual Appointment class, which was generated using the Linq-to-SQL Designer (essentially a Linq ORM to the Appointments table in the db)
member.remarks: Obviously, you should use your own appointment object/classes, and change the code-behind in MonthView.xaml.vb to support a List(Of T) where T is whatever the System.Type is for your appointment class.
member.author: Kirk Davis, February 2009 (in like, 4 hours, and it shows!)
